content.heading: What is Kibodo One?
content.text:
A revolutionary mechanical keyboard

Built from the ground up with a focus on modularity, ergonomics, and aesthetic appeal. Kibodo One features magnetically attachable modules that allow users to customize their typing experience on the fly. The design integrates a side-display, which shows the time, a live count of your words per minute, system information, and allows you to configure the keyboard without requiring an installed app on your PC! content.heading: Design Philosophy
content.text:
Kibodo One represents my belief that peripherals should be extensions of the user, not constraints. Every decision - from the switch selection to the module attachment mechanism - prioritizes the user experience.

The modular design means you can swap components based on your task at the moment: gaming, coding or just typing. The integrated display transforms a functional component into a creative canvas, allowing users to express themselves through custom backgrounds and information displays, extending the PC's functionality.

content.heading: PsychoDuck Tech
content.text: We created this tech 'brand', having under it's name both parts of the project: Kibodo One and Tenki One. We made a mascot for the brand as well! A cute yet crazy and psychotic duck :p

content.heading: The Modular Ecosystem and Tenki One
content.text:
The true innovation of Kibodo One lies in its modular system.

To showcase the real-world functionality of modularity, we created Tenki One, the first module ever for Kibodo, a number pad powered by pogo pins and communicating via Bluetooth LE to Kibodo.

 Each module attaches magnetically to the side of the keyboard, creating a customizable peripheral ecosystem.

Here are some future module ideas:

- **Macro Pad Module**: A small numpad-style module for saving frequently used macros

- **Media Control Module**: Dedicated controls for volume, play/pause, and track switching

- **Game Mode Module**: Specialized buttons for gaming configurations and actions

content.heading: PsychOS
content.text:
PsychOS is the name I gave to the firmware that runs on Kibodo One. (noticed the pun?)

Everything from key scanning to the UI display drawing, was developed by me (excepting the display driver and HID code handling).

I developed it using the Arduino Framework, which is definitely **not ideal** for this kind of project, it was definitely easy on development on the begining, but when requiring higher level code I just kept hitting walls and limitations. Due to limitations in the Arduino framework, key reporting has some issues ‚Äî ESP-IDF would improve this, but requires a full source code rewrite.

I tried making the code as modular and accessible as possible, each part of the keyboard has it's own separate files for the FreeRTOS tasks, which are then all included and started from main.cpp.

And yes, I did waste time developing a custom BLE communication protocol and the rotary enconder driver myself lol...
